description: From musket +â€Ž -oon, after French mousqueton. Compare Italian moschettone.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A firearm, similar to a musket but with a shorter barrel and a large bore. [from 17th c.]
examples: And d'Artagnan set the example. Then, turning toward Planchet, he made him a sign to uncock his musketoon. The Englishmen, convinced of these peaceful proceedings, sheathed their swords grumblingly.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One who is armed with such a musket. [16th c.]
